title: How to Buy Garden Seed

steps.headline: Find seed vendors in your area or online.
steps.description: Before shopping for garden seeds, evaluate the vendors that are at your disposal in person or online. Research seed farmers and seed companies in your area to get a feel for what's available. Browse online seed stores to compare stock, prices, and customer reviews. To narrow down your search, start by searching for vendors offering the particular seeds you are looking for and expand your scope as needed.

steps.headline: Buy from small, reputable companies that emphasize quality production.
steps.description: To get high-quality seeds, avoid buying from large corporations that mass-market their products. Buy from smaller companies that show a commitment to sustaining the environment and producing healthy, organic seeds. Shop at local seed businesses, or look online to expand your search. Quality seeds will likely produce higher yields and healthier plants. Look into how long a seed company has been in business and if there are any consumer complaints against them.

steps.headline: Look for organic seeds to ensure that you have a chemical-free garden.
steps.description: Organic seeds come from parent plants that are pesticide-free and organically grown. These seeds may be heirloom or hybrid. Buy organic seeds to ensure that your own garden has no traces of synthetic pesticides, and to contribute to the harvesting and distribution of chemical-free seeds. Make sure the seeds you buy are labelled "certified organic." If seeds are not specifically labelled organic, they are probably not. Purchase organic seeds to grow non-edible plants as well as fruits and vegetables to ensure a chemical-free garden.

steps.headline: Buy heirloom seeds for plants that are not genetically modified or artificially selected.
steps.description: Heirloom seeds come from plants that have been grown naturally without any artificial adjustments to their genetic makeup or selective breeding. The seeds from these plants will produce the same type of plant they were harvested from. Look for heirloom seeds if you do not wish to grow any genetically modified or artificially bred plants in your garden. "Heirloom" generally signifies that seeds have been harvested and passed down within 1 family or community for at least 50 years. With a few exceptions, GMO seeds are not widely available to members of the general public. However, many plants are bred under controlled conditions to select for specific characteristics (such as size, color, or shape). Heirloom seeds are open-pollinated, allowing them to retain their unique characteristics.

steps.headline: Purchase hybrid seeds if you are interested in "enhanced" plants.
steps.description: Hybrid seeds are crossbred from 2 different parent plants to promote certain desirable traits. These "enhanced" seeds may produce plants that are more disease-resistant or produce larger fruit. Look for hybrid plant seeds if you are interested in plants that may produce unique and "enhanced" crops. Broccolini, a hybrid of broccoli and gai lan, is an example of a hybrid plant. The disadvantage of this type of garden seed is that unique plant genes, affecting things like flavor and texture, may be lost in crossbreeding.

parts.name: Selecting the Right Seeds for Your Garden

steps.headline: Buy locally-harvested seeds to ensure climate-ready crops.
steps.description: Locally-grown seeds are the most likely to withstand your region's climate and unique weather conditions. Look for seeds produced within your region by buying only from local seed companies. Be sure to find out exactly where the seeds were harvested, as some local companies may purchase seeds from other regions. Look for regionally-grown seeds at local farmers markets or local garden stores.

steps.headline: Purchase outsourced seeds that will grow in your climate zone, if preferred.
steps.description: If you can't find locally-sourced seeds, make sure to buy seeds that will grow and thrive in the climate you live in. Information about the climate zone that seeds will thrive in should be provided when you purchase them. If it’s not, research these plants online or ask a specialist at a local garden center for advice. If you live in the U.S., view a map of the country's 10 climate zones on the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) website at http://planthardiness.ars.usda.gov/PHZMWeb/.

steps.headline: Buy warm weather seeds to grow plants in the spring, summer, or fall.
steps.description: Purchase garden seeds for the growing season you want to plant in. Some seeds need cool weather for germination, while others need warm weather and soil to sprout. Choose warm weather seeds if you want to grow things during the late spring, summer, or early fall, when the soil is still relatively warm. Seeds that grow best in a warm environment include cucumbers, tomatoes, eggplants, basil, squash, zinnias, and nasturtiums.

steps.headline: Buy seed trays to germinate warm weather seeds indoors.
steps.description: Warm weather seeds are more sensitive to weather changes and should be sprouted in a controlled climate. Buy seed trays from a garden store or online to germinate your seeds indoors. The length and width of your seed tray should depend on how many seeds you're planting. As a general rule, your tray should be 2 or 3 inches (5.1 or 7.6 cm) deep. The time that your seeds will need to germinate will depend on the type of plants you are growing. For instance, marigold seeds will sprout in 5-7 days, while zinnia seeds will sprout in 7-10 days.

steps.headline: Choose cold-resistant seeds if you want to sow them outdoors.
steps.description: Cold-resistant seeds are the best to plant directly into your garden because they will sprout easily despite cold weather or rough conditions. Make sure that your soil is garden-ready before planting. Choose these seeds if you want an easy planting experience that will not require the transferring of any sprouts to your garden. Notable cold-resistant seeds include kale, lettuce, broccoli, peas, carrots, cilantro, parsley, and cabbage. Root vegetables are well-suited for the direct sowing method of planting because they are difficult to transfer after germination. For instance, buy carrot, beet, or radish seeds.
